summary: Paul Merson reignited his feud with Andros Townsend after the Tottenham midfielder was substituted on for only seven minutes during a 0-0 draw with Burnley. Merson mocked Townsend on Twitter, referencing his brief appearance. This follows Merson's earlier criticism of Townsend's inclusion in the England squad, which he expressed in a Sky Sports column. Townsend responded by scoring a crucial equalizer for England against Italy, prompting Merson to admit his mistake and praise Townsend's performance. Despite this, Merson couldn't resist another jab at Townsend after the Burnley match, indicating that their rivalry persists.

Chelsea have made a formal offer to sign 22-year-old FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto, as confirmed by FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane. If the transfer is completed this summer, Muto will join Chelsea's Dutch partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season. Muto, who recently graduated with an economics degree from Keio University, has scored 16 goals in 37 appearances for FC Tokyo and earned 11 caps for Japan. While a £4 million deal has been discussed, Muto has not yet decided on the move, calling it an "honour" to receive the offer. Chelsea's interest in Muto is unrelated to their £200 million sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber, which begins in the 2015-16 season. Muto has been in strong form this season, scoring three goals in four games and helping FC Tokyo to third place in the J-League.

A large-scale study published in *Pediatrics* found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight or obese as toddlers. The research, involving over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds, revealed that repeated antibiotic use before age two increased the likelihood of weight gain, particularly in boys. The study suggested that antibiotics might disrupt gut bacteria, leading to increased calorie absorption and appetite. While the study did not prove causation, it highlighted a potential link between early antibiotic use and childhood obesity, emphasizing the need for cautious antibiotic prescribing. The findings align with broader concerns about antibiotic overuse, including risks of antibiotic resistance and other health issues like eczema and digestive problems.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard ceremony, an incident witnessed by hundreds of tourists and captured on camera by holidaymaker David Meadwell. The guard, wearing full regalia, lost his footing, knocked his bearskin hat against the sentry box, and dropped his rifle before quickly getting up. The slip, likely caused by metal protectors on his boots, left the guard visibly embarrassed. The Changing of the Guard is a daily summer and alternate-day winter event at Buckingham Palace, involving fully operational soldiers. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident.

The passage discusses the remake of the iconic 1977 miniseries "Roots," which originally depicted the story of Kunta Kinte, an African man captured and sold into slavery in America. The remake, set to air in 2016, will be simulcast by A&E, Lifetime, and History. LeVar Burton, who played Kunta Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce the new version, which aims to be more authentic and contemporary, drawing heavily from Alex Haley's novel "Roots: The Saga of an American Family." The production will involve consultations with scholars to ensure historical accuracy. The remake is intended to reach both fans of the original and a new generation, reflecting on the enduring relevance of the story amidst current racial issues in the U.S.

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, has alleged that in 1978, while working at Clarence House, he was sexually assaulted by palace aides who attempted to force him into an orgy. Lawler claims he was pinned to a chair and groped by a male staff member on his first day, prompting him to leave the job immediately. He reported the incident to palace officials last year after investigations into historical child sex abuse cases involving a VIP paedophile ring began. His complaints were initially ignored but were eventually passed to Scotland Yard. A retired royal aide was interviewed but denied involvement. The Royal Household has pledged full cooperation with the ongoing police investigation.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced they are expecting a child through a rap video parodying the theme song of the '90s sitcom *The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air*. The video, which has garnered over 1.7 million views on YouTube, features the couple rapping about their journey to parenthood, including their initial lie about not being ready for kids and the surprise of conceiving in just two months. The clip ends with a sonogram of their unborn child. The couple shared that the video was created to inform distant loved ones about the pregnancy and expressed surprise at its viral success. They also hinted at possibly making another video after learning the baby's gender. Jesse is the great-great-grandson of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film *Gone With the Wind* sold for $137,000 at a Heritage Auctions event in Beverly Hills. The gray jacket and skirt ensemble, originally slate blue-gray but faded over time, was worn in key scenes, including Scarlett's encounters with Rhett Butler and the shanty town attack. The dress was part of a private collection of over 150 items from the film, owned by James Tumblin, who acquired it for $20 in the 1960s. Tumblin amassed over 300,000 pieces of Hollywood memorabilia, promoting the film and its history. Other notable auction items included Leigh's straw hat ($52,500), Clark Gable's suit ($55,000), and a bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia De Havilland ($30,000). The film, based on Margaret Mitchell's 1936 novel, marked its 75th anniversary last year and featured Hattie McDaniel, the first African-American to win an Academy Award.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents reportedly dangled him over the railing. The incident occurred on a Saturday around 3 pm when the boy slipped from his mother's grasp and fell 10 to 12 feet into the pit. The parents rescued him before emergency services arrived. The boy sustained minor injuries, including bruises and a leg injury, but was not attacked by the cheetahs, which did not approach him. Zoo officials stated that eyewitness accounts suggest the child was dangled over the railing, and the zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family. The exhibit was closed following the incident.

A speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, which had been non-operational for over two years, was recently found angled towards a house's front door. The camera, part of a system decommissioned in 2013 due to outdated technology, was among 300 such devices turned off across the West Midlands. Speed enforcement has since been managed by mobile units, motorway cameras, and patrol officers. Birmingham City Council, aware of the repositioned camera, plans to send an engineer to potentially remove it. The council is developing a pilot program using digital technology at select sites but confirmed the Wellington Road camera would not be included. The homeowners were unavailable for comment.

Usain Bolt, the six-time Olympic gold medallist, will compete for Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3. Bolt expressed his readiness and excitement to represent Jamaica, emphasizing the country's strong relay tradition and his commitment to making the nation proud. JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle highlighted the significance of Bolt's participation, anticipating exceptional performances. The full Jamaican team roster will be announced soon.

Neymar and Dani Alves demonstrated their support for Barcelona by attending the basketball El Clasico, where Barcelona narrowly defeated Real Madrid 85-80 in the Euro League. Despite the win, Real Madrid remains ahead in their Euro League division based on points difference. Neymar, who recently led Brazil to a 1-0 victory over Chile in a challenging match, was accompanied by his sister Rafaella and Alves at the basketball game. Before the international break, Barcelona had also won their football El Clasico, extending their lead in La Liga. Neymar and his team are set to return to La Liga action against Celta Vigo as they pursue a treble of trophies.

Italy is experiencing a significant increase in migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe, with 8,480 migrants rescued from Friday to Monday. Concerns have been raised by Save the Children about 400 potentially missing migrants after a reported shipwreck off the Libyan coast, though the Italian Coast Guard has not confirmed the incident. The Coast Guard conducted search operations but found no evidence of the capsized boat. The International Organization for Migration (IOM) reports that over 10,000 migrants arrived in Italy in the first three months of 2015, with at least 480 deaths recorded this year due to harsh conditions and unsafe vessels. Migrants primarily come from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, often transiting through Libya.

Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger is pleased that Alexis Sanchez chose to join Arsenal over Liverpool, despite not knowing the exact reasons for his decision. Sanchez, who was sought after by several top clubs after leaving Barcelona, has made a significant impact in English football, scoring 19 goals in his first season. Wenger acknowledges that Liverpool's interest in Sanchez might have been influenced by their negotiations over Luis Suárez's transfer to Barcelona. He praises Sanchez's adaptability, work ethic, and ability to energize the team. Wenger also downplays rumors of a potential move for Liverpool's Raheem Sterling and commends Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers for his team's performance despite challenges like Suárez's departure and injuries.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. The current record, set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February, stands at 52.491km. Wiggins, who recently ended his Team Sky career, aims to add this prestigious achievement to his accolades and inspire others to challenge themselves. The event will be held at the Lee Valley VeloPark, with tickets available from April 19 and the attempt broadcast live on Sky Sports. Wiggins is also targeting an eighth Olympic medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. Other notable attempts include those by Alex Dowsett, who will try to break the record on May 2 in Manchester.

Serena Williams, the world No. 1 and twice French Open champion, described her hard-fought victory over Sara Errani in the Fed Cup play-off as an "eye-opener" for her readiness for the claycourt season. Despite winning 4-6, 7-6(3), 6-3, Williams admitted she wasn't as prepared for clay as she thought. The US team, however, lost 3-2 overall after Williams and Alison Riske were defeated in the doubles by Errani and Flavia Pennetta, resulting in the US being relegated to World Group II. Williams, who has won 19 Grand Slam singles titles, acknowledged the need to adjust her game for clay. US captain Mary Joe Fernandez emphasized the need for improvement and expressed hope for a return to the World Group next year.

River Plate is interested in re-signing Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao, who previously played for the Argentine club from 2001 to 2009, scoring 34 goals in 90 appearances. Falcao, currently on loan at Manchester United, has struggled this season, scoring only four Premier League goals. River Plate's vice president, Matias Patanian, expressed the club's desire to bring Falcao back, stating, "We dream of Falcao Garcia. The doors are open." Despite his struggles at United, Falcao has been in good form for Colombia, recently equaling the national team's all-time scoring record with 24 goals. It remains uncertain whether Manchester United will retain him or if he will return to Monaco, his parent club.

Ella Henderson, a 19-year-old X Factor finalist and pop star, has been announced as the face of Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The campaign features Henderson showcasing various hairstyles against a vibrant city background, with images highlighting her glossy, wavy hair and stylish outfits. The partnership, facilitated by the MILES agency, includes a TV advertising campaign featuring Henderson's single "Mirror Man." Henderson expressed her excitement about working with Batiste, a brand she regularly uses. Mark Hargreaves, CEO of Crown Talent & Media Group, praised the collaboration, noting the natural synergy between Henderson and the globally popular dry shampoo brand.

Aaron Siler, a 26-year-old man wanted on a felony probation and parole warrant, was fatally shot by Officer Pablo Torres on March 14 after a vehicle and foot pursuit, during which Siler reportedly armed himself with a weapon. Torres, who is on leave pending the investigation, had also shot and wounded 66-year-old Terry Knight, armed with knives, 10 days earlier. The Kenosha Professional Police Association erected a billboard featuring Torres and his dog, thanking the community for its support, which Siler's family and friends found disrespectful and called for its removal. The police association stated the billboard was not intended to offend but to express gratitude for community support. Investigations into both shootings are ongoing, with the shooting of Knight deemed justified by the District Attorney.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Pakistan border, with three militants also killed in the fighting. The militants, reportedly from the group Jaish al Adl, crossed into Iran from Pakistan. Jaish al Adl, a Sunni Muslim group opposing Iranian influence, claimed responsibility for the attack. Iranian officials have requested Pakistani authorities to apprehend the surviving assailants. Pakistan condemned the attack and stated that its security agencies are investigating the incident, promising to bring any militants who entered Pakistan to justice. This incident follows previous attacks by the same group, including a deadly 2013 attack that killed 14 Iranian border guards. Iran has criticized Pakistan for not controlling militants operating from its territory.

The passage discusses a political exchange in Japan regarding extraterrestrial threats, prompted by a question from former wrestler and current lawmaker Antonio Inoki. Japan's Defense Minister Gen Nakatani assured the Diet that the Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) has never encountered any UFOs from outer space, though they do investigate unidentified flying objects that could violate airspace. Inoki, a well-known figure in Japan for his wrestling career, political activities, and media presence, has a history of unconventional actions, including attempts at diplomacy through wrestling and a reported sighting of a UFO. The discussion reflects past Japanese political considerations of extraterrestrial threats, including a 2007 debate on the legal implications of defending against an alien invasion under Japan's pacifist constitution.

A 35-year-old passenger, Jin Pai, was hospitalized with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after breaking a toilet he was squatting on at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in Hefei, China. Jin was standing on the toilet rim, concerned about cleanliness, when it collapsed and shattered, causing his injuries. He initially called his companions for help but was too embarrassed to shout. Emergency personnel took him to a hospital, where he received dozens of stitches. Jin initially admitted to squatting but later told police he was sitting, possibly to avoid compensation. Authorities deemed the incident an accident and reminded the public that toilets are designed for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, from Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested after a 15-year-old girl discovered a hidden camera in her bathroom, which police traced back to him. Rebbie faces multiple charges, including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. The investigation revealed that Rebbie had been sexually abusing the girl since she was nine and had filmed her and others using the bathroom over a three- to four-year period. Investigators found 41 videos, including close-up images of children's genitalia, which Rebbie uploaded to his computer. Rebbie admitted to purchasing the camera specifically to record the 15-year-old victim. His preliminary hearing is set for May 1, and he is being held on $500,000 bail. The relationship between Rebbie and the girl's family remains unclear.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama's latest photo series, featured in his book *Daughter and Salary Man*, captures unique father-daughter portraits. In each image, daughters stand po-faced while their fathers, dressed in sharp suits, leap energetically into the air, often with dramatic or slightly pained expressions. The photos, set against various Japanese landmarks, aim to showcase the fathers' fun and heroic sides, contrasting their typically serious demeanor. The series has garnered significant online interest for its quirky and curious nature, though little else is known about its origins.

The passage discusses the shifting focus in English cricket from the dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director to the start of the county championship season, with particular attention on Kevin Pietersen. Pietersen, who was controversially dropped from the England team in 2014, is attempting a return to the international set-up by rejoining Surrey. During a team photo session at the KIA Oval, Pietersen appeared reflective yet jovial, engaging with photographers and teammates. His potential return is seen as a step closer following Downton's sacking. Surrey's season begins with a match against Glamorgan on April 19, and Pietersen's performance could influence his chances of rejoining the England team, especially with the upcoming Ashes series.

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, a Romanian club facing relegation, sacked Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week following a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani. Initially fired due to poor performance, Ze Maria was briefly reinstated after owner Angelo Massone reconsidered. However, the defeat led to his final dismissal. Ze Maria, a former Inter Milan and Parma player with 25 caps for Brazil, had replaced Florin Marin in January. Ceahlaul, now 16th in the standings and six points from safety, will appoint Serbian Vanya Radinovic as his replacement.

Radamel Falcao's former Monaco teammate, Nabil Dirar, believes Falcao regrets his unsuccessful loan move to Manchester United, despite not being happy during his time in France. Falcao, who joined United on a season-long loan, has struggled to regain his pre-injury form, scoring only four goals. With United unlikely to pay £46 million to make his transfer permanent, Dirar suggests Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he could have played in the Champions League, even though he was unhappy there.

New Zealand police are seeking public assistance to identify a man who robbed a Christchurch dairy while wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluorescent orange sweatshirt. The incident occurred on Saturday around 12:30 pm, when the masked man demanded cash from the dairy owner's daughter, causing her to flee the shop in fear. The robber took the cash register's till drawer and approximately $1,500 before fleeing the scene. No weapons were used, and the suspect remains at large. Police urge anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers or message them online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, has been arrested twice for inappropriate relationships with underage students. She was first arrested on March 19 after admitting to kissing a 15-year-old student and allowing him to touch her breasts in April of the previous year. Granado was released on bail but was arrested again on March 24 after a second 15-year-old student accused her of having sex with him on two consecutive nights in January. The incidents allegedly occurred in her car near another school in Dallas. Granado has been suspended from teaching and placed on administrative leave. She was released on a $50,000 bail following her second arrest, and it is unclear how she will plead to the new charges. The school district has taken immediate action to ensure she does not interact with students or access school property.

A video showing a crocodile swimming through a marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead pet dog in its jaws has garnered over 500,000 views online. The dog, which belonged to a local bike shop owner, was attacked after approaching the water's edge. Witness Tim Weston, a tourist, described the crocodile holding the dog for hours. The incident occurred near a crocodile sanctuary, highlighting the increasing proximity of these creatures to human areas due to urbanization. Social media reactions ranged from horror to disdain, with some users expressing fear of crocodiles. This event underscores the challenges of coexisting with wildlife in tourist-heavy regions like Puerto Vallarta.

Steve Bruce remains confident that Hull City can avoid relegation from the Premier League despite a 2-0 defeat to Southampton, which left them just two points above the drop zone. Bruce initially aimed for 10 wins to ensure survival but now believes eight or nine might suffice. Hull faces challenging fixtures against top teams like Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United in their remaining six games. Bruce attributes their struggles to long-term injuries to key players, including Mohamed Diame, James Chester, Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and Robert Snodgrass. Despite these setbacks, Bruce is optimistic about their chances, citing the team's resilience and past successes. Meanwhile, Southampton's victory, marked by goals from James Ward-Prowse and Graziano Pelle, moved them to fifth in the table. Manager Ronald Koeman addressed an incident where Sadio Mane attempted to take a penalty instead of Ward-Prowse, emphasizing the importance of adhering to team rules.

Ian Guffick, a teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, was banned from teaching for at least two years after he allowed pupils to alter their SATs exam answers and made changes himself after the exam session had ended. This misconduct led to the annulment of the entire school's SATs results for 2014. Guffick admitted to the allegations, acknowledging his actions constituted unacceptable professional conduct, though he claimed he only asked pupils to make their answers more legible. A panel found his actions dishonest but not fraudulent, noting his remorse and cooperation during the investigation. The Department for Education supported the panel's decision to impose a prohibition order, and Guffick has 28 days to appeal the decision.

Anders Lindegaard, the Manchester United goalkeeper, has had limited playing time at the club, making only 19 league appearances in five seasons and currently being third-choice behind David de Gea and Victor Valdes. Despite his struggles on the pitch, Lindegaard enjoys a fulfilling personal life. He married Swedish model Misse Beqiri in a romantic beach wedding in Mauritius in 2015, and the couple, who have been dating since 2012, have a son together. Beqiri, who has Albanian roots, is active on Instagram, where she shares modeling photos and has over 17,000 followers. Lindegaard, who joined Manchester United in 2010 from Norwegian side Aalesunds, has been told he can leave the club and was linked with a move to FC Midtjylland in January, but no agreement was reached.

The 13 glowing blue letters that once adorned Yankee Stadium failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction, despite an estimated value of $300,000 to $600,000. The only bid, for $260,000, came from a Sotheby's employee attempting to stimulate interest. The letters, which had been displayed since 1976 and removed in 2008, are currently owned by Yankees Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, who purchased them after the stadium's final game. Jackson hoped a new generation would own and enjoy this iconic piece of Yankees and New York City history. In contrast, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 1960s, estimated at $20,000 to $30,000, sold for $112,500 at the same auction.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers addressed Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their professional responsibilities following a week where Sterling was seen inhaling nitrous oxide and both players were pictured with shisha pipes. Rodgers emphasized the importance of their conduct as elite athletes but chose not to discipline them, aiming to move past the incidents. With Steven Gerrard returning from suspension, Rodgers focused on preparing Liverpool for their FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, highlighting the team's readiness to progress after previous near-misses in competitions. He stressed the importance of learning from losses to achieve future success.

Mesut Ozil, Arsenal's playmaker, returned to London after helping Germany secure a 2-0 victory over Georgia in a Euro 2016 qualifier. He shared a photo on Twitter relaxing with his dog, captioning it "Home Sweet Home." Ozil, who missed Arsenal's last game against Newcastle due to illness, is expected to play in the upcoming Premier League match against Liverpool. Despite rumors of being seen in a Berlin nightclub, manager Arsene Wenger dismissed these claims. Since returning from injury in January, Ozil has been in excellent form, contributing four assists and scoring three goals. He expressed that he is adjusting well to English football, appreciating the frequent matches and feeling he fits in perfectly.

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu has dismissed speculation about replacing manager Luis Enrique, stating the club is "very happy" with his performance. Enrique, who took charge last summer on a two-year contract, is close to winning La Liga, with Barcelona still in contention for three trophies this season. Bartomeu praised Enrique's dedication and preparation, particularly ahead of key matches. Barcelona recently defeated Valencia 2-0, with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi, further solidifying their strong position in the league.

Jordan Henderson has agreed to a new long-term contract with Liverpool, worth approximately £100,000 per week, extending until 2020. The 24-year-old midfielder, who has been a key player under manager Brendan Rodgers, has shown significant improvement this season with 13 assists and seven goals. Henderson, signed from Sunderland in 2011 for £16 million, is set to become Liverpool's captain following Steven Gerrard's departure to LA Galaxy. This contract makes him the third major player, after Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho, to secure a contract extension under Rodgers. Meanwhile, negotiations with Raheem Sterling are paused but expected to continue after the season.

Filipe Luis has expressed his desire to remain at Chelsea until the end of his three-year contract, despite interest from his former club Atletico Madrid to re-sign him. Although he has faced challenges securing the left-back position at Chelsea, Luis stated he is happy at the club. His focus is now on the Premier League title race, with Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho emphasizing the need for continued focus and effort in the remaining nine challenging games. Luis believes the team is prepared to handle the pressure of the title run-in.

Nathan Hughes, the Wasps No 8, had his three-match ban overturned on appeal after initially being suspended for accidentally kneeing George North in the head during a try-scoring incident on March 27. The disciplinary panel originally deemed Hughes reckless, leading to a red card and suspension, but the appeal panel ruled the collision was accidental, rescinding the ban. North, who was knocked unconscious, has been advised to take a month off due to concussion symptoms, marking his third head injury in two months. Hughes missed Wasps' Champions Cup quarter-final loss to Toulon but is now free to play, though he is unlikely to feature until April 26. The decision sparked widespread criticism, with many defending Hughes, arguing the ban was unjust given the lack of intent.

A fiery, deep red sunset in Washington on Sunday, captured by photographer Tim Durkan, was caused by smoke from wildfires in Siberia. The fires, initially started by farmers burning grass, grew out of control due to strong winds on April 14, destroying dozens of villages. The smoke was carried by atmospheric winds across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest, affecting regions like Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia. The intense red hues in the sunset resulted from smoke particles filtering out shorter wavelength colors (greens, blues, yellows, and purples), allowing red and orange to dominate. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve, and the vivid sunsets will fade.

Becky Schoenig of St. Louis, Missouri, had her brand new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway. After a month, the car was found and returned to her, but with modifications: red rims, red detailing, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Instead of being upset, Schoenig humorously thanked the thieves on Facebook for "pimping out" her car. However, she is having the car professionally cleaned to remove the smell of cigarettes and marijuana. Schoenig is also creating a smoothie at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, to honor Mick Sexton, the man who helped locate her car. Friends describe Schoenig as vibrant and humorous.

Manchester City players, including stars like Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart, and Yaya Toure, stand to lose £500,000 each in bonuses if the club fails to qualify for the Champions League this season. The team, currently in fourth place, is on incentivized contracts to comply with financial fair play rules. A defeat in the Manchester derby has left their European hopes uncertain, with Liverpool close behind in the standings. The top three Premier League teams qualify automatically for the Champions League, while the fourth-place team must win a qualifying round. Manager Manuel Pellegrini acknowledged the team's poor performance in recent months, including early exits from the FA Cup and Champions League. The club also faces challenges in attracting top talent, such as Juventus midfielder Paul Pogba, who is also a target for Manchester United. United's manager, Louis van Gaal, expressed confidence in securing high-profile signings in the upcoming transfer window.

Manchester United's Under 18s defeated Manchester City 1-0 in a 'mini-derby' at Moss Lane, with Callum Gribbin scoring the winning goal through a superb free-kick. The match, attended by nearly 1,000 spectators, featured a predominantly English and Mancunian lineup, with 13 out of 22 starters being English, including 10 from Manchester. United's coach, Paul McGuinness, aimed to replicate a senior match experience, employing a three-at-the-back formation. Despite City's efforts, including a close attempt by Marcus Wood, United secured the win, leaving them two points behind league leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand. The match highlighted the potential of young talents on both teams, suggesting promising futures in senior football.

Joe Hart, the England and Manchester City goalkeeper, praised Gianluigi Buffon as a "legend of the game" after Buffon earned his 147th cap for Italy in a 1-1 draw against England. Hart, who celebrated his 50th cap in the same match, expressed admiration for Buffon's longevity and professionalism at 37 years old, calling him an inspiration. Hart, 10 years younger than Buffon, emphasized his desire to continue improving and accumulating more caps for both his club and country, stating that 50 caps at his age is a significant achievement but not the end of his ambitions.

Chipotle is entering the $70 billion food delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app to offer delivery in 67 cities. The service will include a 9% service charge, with delivery fees starting at $5, depending on distance and demand. This marks a shift for Chipotle, which previously declined third-party delivery collaborations. The move aligns with a broader trend, as other chains like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also exploring or launching delivery services. Additionally, Chipotle has gained attention for visits from political figures, including presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Marco Rubio.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings, have publicly urged the Justice Department to drop the death penalty for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was convicted on all 30 charges related to the attacks. In a Boston Globe op-ed, Bill and Denise Richard described the profound impact of losing their 8-year-old son and the severe injuries sustained by their daughter, Jane. They expressed their desire to avoid prolonged appeals and emotional trauma by advocating for a life sentence without parole instead of the death penalty. They emphasized their hope to move forward and heal, both for their family and the community. The bombings killed three people, including Martin, and injured over 200 others. Tsarnaev's brother, Tamerlan, was killed in a police shootout in 2013.

A mystery billionaire has transformed a Boeing 747 into a £400 million luxury private jet, customized over three years to serve as a lavish home in the sky. The jet, which typically accommodates 600 passengers, now features a master bedroom, eight additional beds, multiple lounges, a dining room with an adjoining kitchen, a conference room, and an office/guest bedroom. Designed to host dozens of guests, the interior resembles a high-end hotel, complete with plush furnishings, a private chef, and a layout that prioritizes comfort and exclusivity. The jet is one of the most luxurious private planes ever built, offering amenities far beyond traditional first-class commercial flights.

SpaceX successfully launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying the uncrewed Dragon cargo spacecraft to the International Space Station (ISS) from Cape Canaveral, Florida. However, the attempt to land the rocket's first stage on a floating barge failed, as the rocket tipped over upon landing. This marks SpaceX's second unsuccessful attempt at such a landing, following a similar failure in January. Despite these setbacks, SpaceX aims to eventually master rocket landings to reduce space travel costs significantly. The Dragon spacecraft is set to deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies, including research equipment and an espresso maker, to the ISS. After unloading, the crew will load the Dragon with over 3,000 pounds of materials to return to Earth, where it will splash down in the Pacific Ocean. This mission represents SpaceX's sixth resupply trip to the ISS and its second launch attempt for this mission after a weather-related scrub on Monday.

Priscilla Presley will serve as a witness at the first wedding to be held at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas, located at the Westgate Hotel. The chapel is part of a contest launched with NBC's *Today* show, where an Elvis-obsessed couple can win the "ultimate wedding," including a free ceremony, reception, a two-night hotel suite, airfares, and concert tickets to the Elvis Experience show. The winning couple, announced on Monday, will marry on April 23. Priscilla emphasized that the chapel is a first-class, serious venue, and no Elvis impersonators are allowed. The chapel is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside Memphis, featuring Elvis's artifacts. Couples must submit videos or photos explaining why they deserve to win.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can still catch Manchester City in the Premier League, despite being four points behind. Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet both played their 47th game of the season in a 2-0 win over Newcastle United, equalling the record for appearances in the top five European leagues this campaign. After recent disappointing results, Liverpool regained form with goals from Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen, who scored his first Anfield goal. Henderson emphasized the importance of continuing to win games to close the gap with City. Newcastle had a strong penalty appeal denied, but Liverpool secured a crucial victory in their pursuit of Champions League qualification.

Roma ended a four-month winless streak at home with a 1-0 victory over Napoli in Serie A, thanks to a 25th-minute goal by Miralem Pjanic following a swift counter-attack. Goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis played a crucial role, making several key saves to secure the win. This victory moved Roma four points ahead of city rivals Lazio in the race for Champions League places. Napoli extended their winless streak to five matches and remained fifth in the standings. The match was marked by tight security due to past incidents, with no reported problems. Roma was without injured captain Francesco Totti and forward Gervinho, but Pjanic's performance was pivotal. Napoli had a potential penalty claim denied, and De Sanctis continued to excel in the second half, ensuring Roma's victory.

The passage describes a lackluster League One match between Doncaster Rovers and Fleetwood Town, which ended in a 0-0 draw at the Keepmoat Stadium. The game was uneventful, testing the patience of even the most dedicated fans. Due to the lack of notable action, Doncaster's media team struggled to compile match highlights, ultimately creating a very brief 27-second video for the club's YouTube channel, featuring only 14 seconds of actual match footage, including the kick-off, a goal kick, and the final whistle. The passage humorously suggests the video is a "must-see" for football fans, highlighting the dull nature of the match.

The passage describes a unique and affectionate relationship between Roland Giroux and his blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid fish first bred in Taiwan in 1986. Despite the common belief that marine pets cannot interact with humans through touch, Giroux has developed a bond with his fish, which enjoys being stroked and massaged. The fish, initially shy, now seeks out Giroux's hand for interaction, even swimming up his arm and circling his fingers. Giroux spends at least 15 minutes daily playing with and massaging the fish, which has become so accustomed to this interaction that it becomes frustrated if not played with. The fish used to share its tank with two others, but they were removed due to bullying. Giroux's interaction with the fish began with hand-feeding frozen blood worms, leading to the fish becoming more sociable and enjoying physical contact. The passage concludes with the fish appearing saddened when Giroux removes his hand from the tank, highlighting the depth of their bond.

Ben Stokes, known for his fiery and aggressive character, has returned to the England cricket team after a year of ups and downs. His past incidents, such as breaking his wrist by punching a locker and clashing with Marlon Samuels, highlight his need to channel his aggression effectively. England coach Peter Moores has played a key role in managing Stokes, advising him on how to balance his natural exuberance with controlled aggression. Stokes' ability to contribute runs and wickets is valued, and England aims to nurture his potential by giving him consistent playing opportunities. While his feisty nature is seen as an asset, it must be managed carefully to avoid pigeonholing him. England is focused on helping Stokes and other young players like Chris Jordan grow into the international game, with an emphasis on their long-term development.

Wales' crucial Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium on June 12 at the Cardiff City Stadium has sold out all 33,000 tickets. Both teams lead Group B with 11 points each, but Belgium holds the top spot due to a superior goal difference. Wales' recent 3-0 victory over Israel has boosted hopes of qualifying for their first major tournament since the 1958 World Cup. The Football Association of Wales reported high demand for tickets, leading to a sell-out. Despite speculation about using the larger Millennium Stadium, UEFA rules and the team's preference for the Cardiff City Stadium ensured the match would be held there. Wales last played at the Millennium Stadium in 2011.

England coach John Peacock has announced the squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria, where England are the defending champions. The team, which qualified with a perfect record, is in Group D with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland. Their first match is against Italy on May 7. The squad includes players from various Premier League clubs, such as Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, and Arsenal's Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi, the latter being a first-time call-up. Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold return after missing the Elite Round qualifiers. England's other group matches are against Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13.

Manchester City are interested in signing 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, who is considered one of the top talents from the club's youth system. Patoulidis has also drawn attention from Arsenal and Barcelona, having previously turned down a move to Barcelona's La Masia academy at age 12 to focus on his studies. City have engaged in talks with Anderlecht's chairman, Roger Vanden Stock, to negotiate a compensation deal as part of their strategy to secure young talent for the future.

A 33-year-old transgender escort, Vanessa Santillan, was found strangled and beaten to death in a flat in Fulham, southwest London, at the end of March. A 23-year-old man has been arrested in connection with her death but has been bailed and is required to return for further questioning. Santillan, a Mexican national who worked as an escort in London, Paris, and Miami, suffered fatal injuries to her head and neck. Police are appealing for information from anyone who had contact with her in the hours before her death. The investigation, led by Detective Chief Inspector Rebecca Reeves, aims to determine the circumstances surrounding her death. Santillan had expressed her love for London and Paris on social media prior to her death.

A woman named Dawn, who has suffered seven miscarriages, appeared on *The Jeremy Kyle Show* to confront her friend Jamie, a convicted burglar, after discovering that £207 saved for a gravestone for her deceased baby, Daniel James, had been stolen. Dawn suspected Jamie and his girlfriend Carol, who were living with her and her partner (also named Jamie). A lie detector test confirmed Jamie had taken the money, despite initially denying it. Jamie later confessed via a Facebook message, blaming Carol. Dawn expressed her devastation, feeling betrayed after saving for the gravestone to honor her baby. The emotional confrontation ended with Dawn in tears, storming off the stage.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, a persecuted minority group, on Wednesday, with most being women, children, the ill, or elderly. The release was coordinated with the help of Arab tribal leaders, and the freed individuals were received by Peshmerga forces and taken to Irbil, the Kurdish regional capital. The exact reason for the release remains unclear. ISIS has previously released other Yazidis, primarily children and the elderly, since attacking their towns in northern Iraq last summer. The group's brutal campaign against the Yazidis, including killings, enslavement, and displacement, has caused a significant humanitarian crisis. An international coalition, including the U.S., responded with airstrikes and aid efforts. The Yazidis, a pre-Islamic religious community, have long faced persecution and make up less than 1% of Iraq's population.

Harry Kane, the Tottenham striker who has had a remarkable season, is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards. A new animated video by Copa90 showcases some of Kane's best goals and celebrations from the season, including his long-range strike against Chelsea, a headed goal against Arsenal, and his goal on his England debut. The video, titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?', has been released ahead of the awards ceremony, where Kane is competing against players like Chelsea's Eden Hazard and Arsenal's Alexis Sanchez for the top prize.

Jamie Carragher supports Brendan Rodgers as the right manager for Liverpool despite a third consecutive trophy-less season and a likely finish outside the top four. Carragher believes Rodgers should not be judged solely on one game and emphasizes the need for better player integration and signings to improve the team. He also highlights Rodgers' responsibility to identify areas for improvement. Carragher, who received a Beacon Award for his community work on Merseyside, expressed hope that his efforts through the 23 Foundation would inspire young people in underprivileged areas, reflecting his commitment to giving back to the community.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his brightly colored plastic Nerf gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport after it was flagged as a security risk during an X-ray scan. Security officers frisked James and performed a thorough pat-down, which his father, Phil Hayward, criticized as "ludicrous" and "over-zealous." The family, traveling to Lanzarote for a 10-day holiday, chose not to argue to avoid missing their flight. Upon returning, James was given a replacement toy gun. East Midlands Airport apologized for the inconvenience but defended the decision, citing government regulations that prohibit items resembling prohibited objects, including replica or model guns. The airport had offered to mail the toy back to the family.

A 31-year-old man named Rich from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. He listed specific requirements for his ideal partner, including being a non-drinker and non-smoker, fit, attractive, reliable, honest, loyal, good at cooking, and skilled in household tasks. Rich offered various incentives, such as accommodation, a company car, phone, laptop, and a gym membership of her choice. He described himself as athletic, heavily tattooed, financially successful, and passionate about outdoor activities. Rich emphasized that his partner would enjoy numerous benefits and that all reasonable offers would be considered, though former partners need not apply. Daily Mail Australia attempted but failed to contact him.

Football Association chairman Greg Dyke has received support from five former England managers—Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren—for his proposals to increase the minimum number of home-grown players in club squads from eight to 12 and redefine "home-grown" as players trained in England for three years before age 18. These changes aim to address the shrinking pool of English talent at the top level, which the former managers argue is a disadvantage for England's national team. They warn that failing to adopt these reforms could further hinder England's chances of winning major tournaments, such as the World Cup. Despite opposition from the Premier League, the former managers highlight the emergence of young talents like Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling, and Harry Kane as evidence that England can still produce top players, but they need more opportunities to succeed.

In the latest episode of *Poldark*, Demelza Poldark, played by Eleanor Tomlinson, gives birth to her and Ross Poldark's (Aidan Turner) daughter. The timeline of the pregnancy has drawn attention for its rapid progression, with Demelza going from announcing her pregnancy in the previous episode to giving birth in the next, seemingly skipping eight months in a short span. Fans have humorously noted the show's tendency to compress pregnancy timelines, comparing it to a previous storyline involving Elizabeth. Despite the timeline inconsistencies, Ross's affection for Demelza is evident, solidifying their relationship. Ross, a popular heartthrob, remains devoted to Demelza, leaving fans wistful but acknowledging his commitment.

Leicester City manager Nigel Pearson has emphasized the importance of his team maintaining focus on their own performance and not being distracted by the results of their relegation rivals. Despite being at the bottom of the Premier League table, Leicester has shown signs of improvement with back-to-back wins, including a dramatic 3-2 victory over West Brom, thanks to Jamie Vardy's injury-time winner. Pearson acknowledges the increased optimism but stresses the need for the team to concentrate on their remaining games to secure their survival, as their fate is still in their own hands. He warns against over-optimism and highlights the importance of staying grounded and focused on their objectives.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara has set a record for the longest mammal migration ever recorded, swimming nearly 14,000 miles from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. This journey surpassed the previous record held by a humpback whale. Varvara's trip, tracked by Oregon State University scientists, included visits to three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, suggesting she may be an eastern gray whale rather than an endangered western gray whale as previously thought. This discovery could imply that some western gray whales are actually eastern grays, potentially reducing the already low population of western gray whales, estimated at 150. The findings may prompt a reevaluation of genetic differences between the two groups.

A 1,000ft stretch of seabed unexpectedly rose to the surface overnight along the coastline of Japan's Shiretoko Peninsula on Hokkaido Island, creating a new landmass up to 50ft high, 1,000-1,640ft long, and 100ft wide. Geologists attribute this phenomenon to a nearby landslide caused by melting ice and snow, which forced the underwater area upward. Local residents reported no tremors or sounds during the event, and authorities confirmed it is unrelated to the recent earthquake in Nepal. The landslide is not expected to expand further, and marine organisms like seaweed and sea urchins remain attached to the newly exposed land.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied rumors of leaving Paris Saint-Germain (PSG) this summer, expressing his love for the club, city, and teammates. Despite a recent disagreement with manager Laurent Blanc after being dropped for a Champions League match against Chelsea, Van der Wiel insists he is happy at PSG and wants to sign a new contract. However, PSG's interest in Barcelona's Dani Alves raises questions about Van der Wiel's future with the club.

Carlos Tevez has expressed his desire to leave Juventus this summer to return to his former club Boca Juniors in Argentina, despite having a contract with Juventus until 2016. Boca Juniors' president, Daniel Angelici, confirmed that the club is close to finalizing Tevez's return but emphasized that he must first terminate his contract with Juventus. Tevez, who has been a key player for Juventus and is currently the league's top scorer with 17 goals this season, has always intended to end his career at Boca Juniors, where he began his professional career. Juventus, though reluctant to lose him, has started looking for potential replacements. Tevez's international manager, Tata Martino, stated that the move would not affect his future with the Argentina national team.

Bayern Munich secured a dominant 6-1 victory over Porto in the Champions League quarter-final, advancing to the semi-finals with an aggregate win. Key goals came from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and a brace from Robert Lewandowski. Despite Porto's initial two-goal lead from the first leg, they were overwhelmed by Bayern's performance. During the match, Bayern manager Pep Guardiola tore his trousers, revealing his underwear, which he humorously addressed post-match. Guardiola also removed his suit blazer later in the game. The victory showcased Bayern's superiority and left their European rivals wary of their form.

A multi-vehicle crash involving ten people, including four children, occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale, on Wednesday afternoon. Three vehicles collided, resulting in injuries ranging from chest and shoulder pain to abdominal pain and hand lacerations. A 40-year-old man and a five-year-old boy were airlifted to Princess Alexandra Hospital, followed by a 27-year-old woman and a six-year-old girl. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries. Emergency crews rescued one person trapped in a vehicle, and the highway was closed for several hours with diversions in place.

The passage discusses the upcoming Premier League match between Arsenal and Chelsea, highlighting Arsenal midfielder Mesut Ozil's excitement for the game, as shown by his new Apple Watch, which he compared to a device from the TV show *Knight Rider*. Ozil is expected to start in the crucial match, with Arsenal trailing Chelsea by 10 points. The text also mentions the return of Jack Wilshere from injury, with club legend Ray Parlour expressing optimism about Wilshere's potential if he can maintain fitness, while noting concerns over his injury history. The match is set for Sunday at 4pm at the Emirates Stadium.

Mark Clattenburg has been appointed to referee the upcoming Manchester derby between United and City at Old Trafford. Despite controversy and accusations of favoring United, Clattenburg has only issued two red cards this Premier League season, both to United players. City captain Vincent Kompany is suspended for the derby due to a red card received during an international match. United are in strong form, having won their last five league games, while City have struggled recently. The derby could be pivotal in determining who finishes second in the league, with Chelsea expected to win the title. Clattenburg will be assisted by Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as the fourth official.

Bob Katter, a federal MP, has sparked controversy by accusing the Queensland Government of treating embattled MP Billy Gordon as a "little black puppet on a string." Katter made this statement in response to assumptions that Gordon would resign after being accused of domestic violence and failing to disclose his criminal history. Gordon, who has since left the Queensland Labor Party, announced he would remain in parliament as an independent, threatening the government's slim majority. Katter, who is of Lebanese descent, defended his use of the term "black puppet," citing his own experiences with racism and claiming the government's actions had racial overtones. The statement has drawn criticism on social media, with some questioning Katter's choice of words and his decision to speak on Gordon's behalf. Katter compared Gordon's situation to other federal MPs who he claimed had become government puppets, but he expressed confidence that Gordon would maintain his independence.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Downers Grove, Illinois, was born with cerebral palsy but is using dance to challenge stereotypes and inspire others. Despite facing bullying and judgment, she creates videos to show that people with disabilities are not fundamentally different from others. Dayna aims to change perceptions in media and fashion industries, emphasizing that while she may do things differently, she should not be treated differently. Her videos, including one set to Taylor Swift's "Shake It Off," aim to turn negativity into positivity and inspire others. Dayna, who was told she might never walk, now dances, drives, attends college, and has started motivational speaking at local schools.

Orlando City, an MLS team with a significant Latin-American fanbase, has expressed interest in signing Manchester United's Javier Hernandez, who is currently on loan at Real Madrid. Hernandez, a Mexican international, would be a major commercial asset for Orlando, which is coached by Adrian Heath. Despite his struggles at Real Madrid, Hernandez has attracted interest from eight European clubs, including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan. Manchester United is willing to sell him for around £8 million. Meanwhile, Manchester United has made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old Andreas Pereira, who has drawn interest from several European clubs, including Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord, after rejecting United's initial offer. Pereira was on the bench for United's recent match against Aston Villa.

A gang of at least three individuals poured gasoline on a white Dodge Charger at a South Los Angeles gas station early Saturday morning and set it on fire after an argument with the driver. The driver reported that the suspects attempted to carjack him, pulling out a gun, which prompted him to flee. The suspects then doused the car in gasoline and ignited it while two passengers were still inside. Fortunately, no one was injured, but the car was completely destroyed. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as arson, and the suspects remain at large. Surveillance footage is being used in the ongoing investigation.

A southern Iowa chiropractor, Charles Manuel, has surrendered his state license after being accused of accepting sex as payment for his services and performing exorcisms on patients. Manuel admitted to these misdeeds and agreed not to apply for reinstatement for at least 10 years. Despite these allegations, he received outstanding patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com. The agreement stipulates that Manuel must prove the circumstances leading to his license revocation no longer exist before he can resume practicing. These circumstances included bartering sex for services and advising patients to stop taking prescribed medications. Manuel's former practice address appears to be a residential home in Lamoni, Iowa.

A U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane was intercepted by a Russian SU-27 Flanker over the Baltic Sea in international airspace north of Poland. The U.S. described the Russian pilot's maneuvers as "unsafe and unprofessional" due to their aggressive nature and close proximity. Russia claimed the U.S. plane was flying toward its border with its transponder off, a claim the U.S. denied. The Pentagon and State Department plan to address the incident through diplomatic channels. This is not the first such encounter; a similar incident occurred a year ago over the Sea of Okhotsk, which the U.S. deemed highly dangerous. U.S. and Russian aircraft frequently encounter each other in Northern Europe and near Alaska.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle, along with his gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools, was stolen from his car in the parking lot of the Marriott Springhill Suites in Salt Lake City on March 27. The rifle, secured in a hard case with padlocks and chains, was forcibly taken by breaking the car's rear window and using a rope or cable to pull the case through the shattered window. The theft occurred just days before President Obama's visit to Utah. Police found skid marks, rope pieces, and the broken rifle case handle at the scene. Some of the agent's belongings were recovered at a nearby hotel, but the rifle remains missing. The hotel lacks surveillance cameras, and the rifle's serial number has been entered into the National Crime Information Computer. It is unclear if the thief specifically targeted the agent's car.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of murdering his elderly neighbor, Terrence Freebody, in July 2012 in Canberra. The attack involved stomping on Freebody's head, cutting his throat, and stabbing him multiple times. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen testified that Costa likely suffered from dementia and alcohol abuse, which compromised his mental state during the incident. Evidence, including erratic behavior and a trail of feces, supported claims of his confused state. The prosecution suggested Costa feigned memory issues, but Mullen denied this, asserting Costa's dementia was genuine. Costa's mental state is pivotal to the case, as proving his unstable mindset could lead to a not guilty verdict.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley's decision to take a penalty in their 1-0 win against Burnley, despite Barkley missing the 10th-minute spot-kick. Barkley, who had not taken a penalty before, stepped up instead of Leighton Baines, who has a strong penalty record (15 out of 16 in the Premier League). Martinez supported Barkley's choice, stating that multiple players, including Romelu Lukaku if he had been on the pitch, could take penalties based on their confidence. Barkley's penalty was saved by Burnley goalkeeper Tom Heaton, but the miss did not cost Everton as Kevin Mirallas scored the winning goal later in the match. Martinez praised Barkley for taking responsibility, and Baines reportedly supported the decision.

Two passengers aboard the Holland America Line cruise ship ms Ryndam were found dead in their stateroom in Puerto Rico, with initial indications suggesting a murder-suicide. The incident occurred on Thursday at 11:30 a.m., and the cabin was secured immediately, with authorities, including the FBI, notified and investigating. The ship, which departed from Tampa, Florida, on March 29 for a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise, is currently in San Juan, Puerto Rico. The cleaning staff discovered the bodies after knocking on the cabin door. The cruise line is fully cooperating with the investigation, and the authorities will determine the official cause of the deaths.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, has successfully led Curacao to the second round of CONCACAF World Cup qualifying for the 2018 tournament. Curacao advanced by drawing 2-2 with Montserrat in the second leg, winning 4-3 on aggregate, following a 2-1 victory in the first leg. A crucial 87th-minute goal by substitute Charlton Vicento secured their progression. Curacao will next face Cuba in June. Kluivert, whose mother is from Curacao, has a notable history in football, including reaching the 1998 World Cup semi-finals as a player and serving as an assistant coach under Louis van Gaal at the 2014 World Cup.

Esteban Cambiasso, a highly decorated footballer with numerous major European titles, including the Champions League and Serie A, views keeping Leicester City in the Premier League as equivalent to winning a trophy. Despite Leicester being seven points adrift at the bottom with only eight games left, Cambiasso remains optimistic about their chances of avoiding relegation. He emphasizes the importance of the team's objective to stay in the league and believes they still have a chance to secure enough points. Cambiasso, who joined Leicester on a one-year deal, has become a key player and is content with his life in the East Midlands, potentially considering staying beyond his current contract.

A 23-year-old mother, Gemma, risks being banned from seeing her two young children by her own mother, Debbie, due to her irresponsible behavior. Gemma, who has two children under five by different fathers, handed them over to Debbie when they were four months old. Debbie, who has been raising the children alone, is considering banning Gemma from her home and from seeing the children because of Gemma's excessive drinking, partying, and suspected theft, including stealing an iPad from one of the children. Gemma admits to past thefts from her mother but denies stealing the iPad. Debbie, who has cared for the children since infancy, feels Gemma is unfit to be a mother and prioritizes her party lifestyle over her children.

In a match between Chelsea and Manchester United at Stamford Bridge, Eden Hazard scored the opening goal for Chelsea, giving them a 1-0 lead. However, the goal was controversial due to a strong challenge by Chelsea captain John Terry on Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao in the build-up. Terry's tackle from behind caused Falcao to lose possession, leading to a loose ball that Cesc Fabregas collected, initiating the move that resulted in Hazard's goal. Sky Sports pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness agreed during halftime analysis that Terry's challenge was a foul and should have been penalized. Souness described it as a "forearm smash," Henry expressed sympathy for Falcao, and Redknapp acknowledged it was a foul despite Falcao's potential to stay on his feet.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on a Texas freeway near Dallas, but all occupants, including Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver, were safely evacuated. The fire, captured on video by Michael Barnett, started after a rear tire blew out and destroyed the bus's back lounge, though Scott's Bible was spared. The band's other members were not on the bus. Lady Antebellum is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards in Arlington, Texas.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman, a physicist at Dundee University, is developing a space-based laser system to convert sunlight into energy using satellites equipped with mirrors and semiconductors. This energy would be transmitted back to Earth as laser light, potentially making solar power viable in regions like Scotland and enabling rapid power restoration in disaster-hit areas. Initial trials in Scotland were successful, with plans to expand testing to Portugal. Unlike fictional depictions, these lasers are not powerful enough to cause harm. Separately, researchers in Tokyo have proposed using lasers on the International Space Station to target and eliminate small space debris, though this system also lacks weapon-grade power. Dr. Quarterman acknowledges potential concerns about satellite control but emphasizes the non-weaponized nature of the technology.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted paedophile with a history of sexual offences involving young girls, has gone missing from a psychiatric unit in Hampshire. He was last seen leaving a hospital near Hook on Tuesday evening. Munden, who has a "fanatical obsession" with young girls, was detained under the Mental Health Act after being convicted of sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus. He also has a history of possessing indecent images of children and was described as autistic with mild learning difficulties. Authorities have launched a manhunt, urging the public to report any sightings, as Munden poses a significant risk. He may have shaved off his beard and is described as 5ft 8ins tall, of heavy build, with dark hair.

A Los Angeles judge ordered V. Stiviano to repay over $2.6 million in gifts she received from Donald Sterling, following a lawsuit filed by his wife, Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling. Shelly accused Stiviano of targeting wealthy older men and claimed Donald used marital funds to buy her luxury items, including cars and a duplex. Stiviano argued the gifts were given willingly and denied taking advantage of Sterling. The court's decision was celebrated by Shelly's lawyer as a victory for recovering assets and setting a precedent for spouses to reclaim damages from recipients of such gifts. The case stems from Donald Sterling's racist remarks, which led to his NBA ban and loss of ownership rights in the Los Angeles Clippers.

Thierry Henry has criticized Arsenal's transfer strategy and emphasized the need for the club to sign four top-quality players—a goalkeeper, a center back, a defensive midfielder, and a striker—to compete for the Premier League title. Speaking as a Sky Sports pundit after Arsenal's goalless draw with Chelsea, Henry argued that Olivier Giroud, despite scoring 14 league goals this season, is not sufficient to lead Arsenal to a title win. He compared Arsenal's situation to Chelsea's successful signings of Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fabregas, and Diego Costa, which helped them dominate the league. Henry urged Arsenal to strengthen their squad to remain competitive and challenge for the title.

A young woman, who endured years of sexual abuse by Maurice Van Ryn, a wealthy NSW businessman and former Bega Cheese boss, has described the severe and lasting impact of his actions on her life. Van Ryn has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim, who cannot be named, told Sydney's District Court that she was unaware the abuse was wrong as a child and only spoke out after learning Van Ryn had been caught. She expressed fear for her future relationships, struggles with depression, self-harm, and suicidal thoughts, and worries about Van Ryn's eventual release. The hearing is ongoing.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, is nearing a return to action after being sidelined for over a year due to a serious knee injury sustained in March 2014. Despite his absence, Gnabry had impressed during the previous season before his injury. He recently played 90 minutes for Arsenal's Under-21 team in a 1-0 loss to Reading, marking his second full game in a week. Gnabry expressed optimism about his recovery, stating he feels "better and better" and is looking forward to his next game.

Jacob Phillips, a 23-year-old accountant, died after falling 70 feet down a cliff in Penarth, South Wales, while attempting to avoid paying a taxi fare. After a night out drinking in Cardiff with friends, Phillips and his companions exited the taxi under the pretense of using an ATM but then fled in different directions. Phillips ran into a dark, disused area called the Northern Promenade, where he accidentally fell over a fence and down the cliff. His body was discovered the next morning by a dog walker. The coroner ruled his death as accidental, noting that Phillips was likely disoriented and unaware of the cliff's proximity. Phillips, a University of Birmingham graduate, had been working for the clothing label Pretty Green and was visiting his mother in Wales for Christmas.

The passage highlights the lack of compensation for thousands of holidaymakers affected by last summer's passport delays, despite the Passport Office making a £42 million profit during the chaos. Managers received bonuses of up to £3,500, while only 2,191 compensation claims were approved, totaling £203,066, with an average payout of £92.68. Many families paid extra for rushed services or missed trips entirely, yet ministers refused blanket refunds, citing concerns over setting a precedent. The Home Affairs Committee, led by Keith Vaz, criticized the lack of compensation, calling the situation a "fiasco." Examples of affected individuals, such as Mathew Bean and Hayley Kirkham, who lost £1,500 on a trip to Morocco, illustrate the personal impact of the delays.

A 1930s timewarp home in Horfield, Bristol, is up for sale, retaining its original features, including stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, a mint green and black bathroom, wood-panelled hallway, and vintage kitchen cupboards. The semi-detached property, with a guide price of £200,000–£250,000, also includes retro food tins and a brick open-face fire. While some modern updates, like double glazing, have been made, the cost of further renovations may deter developers. The house, described as a collector’s paradise, is set to be auctioned on April 30 and is ideal for antique enthusiasts or families seeking a historic home.

Colin Kaepernick started his professional career as a backup to Alex Smith but became the San Francisco 49ers' starting quarterback in 2012 after Smith suffered a concussion. He led the team to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
"Soul Food" is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans and spent much of her early life there before relocating to Texas and later to San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, connecting the New Jersey Turnpike (Interstate 95) at exits 16E and 17 in Secaucus to New York State Route 495 inside the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast through its NBCUniversal division, NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, raised in Leytonstone, East London, and Colchester, Essex, attended Stanway School, where he met Graham Coxon and later formed the band Blur. Blur's debut album, *Leisure*, was released in 1991 to mixed reviews. The band, influenced by various genres like alternative rock, trip hop, and pop, achieved worldwide success with their self-titled album in 2001. That same year, Rage Against the Machine reunited and performed at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival, marking their first performance in seven years. Their fourth studio album, *Renegades*, was released on December 5, 2000, by Epic Records.

The S&P BSE SENSEX, also known as the BSE 30 or simply SENSEX, is a free-float market-weighted stock market index comprising 30 financially stable and well-established companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE). Tata Motors, one of these companies, is listed on the BSE, where it is part of the SENSEX index, as well as on the National Stock Exchange of India and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia. With approximately 92.7 million people, it ranks as the 14th-most-populous country globally and the ninth-most-populous in Asia. It shares borders with China, Laos, Cambodia, and Thailand, and is near the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia across the South China Sea. Since 2000, Vietnam has experienced significant economic growth, ranking highest in the Global Growth Generators Index among major economies in 2011. It remains one of the world's four one-party socialist states officially adhering to communism.

"Dreamer" is a 2005 American sports drama film, marking John Gatins' debut as both writer and director. The film centers around themes of sports and personal drama, though specific plot details are not provided in the passage.

Bhagat Singh was a prominent Indian socialist revolutionary known for his dramatic acts of violence against British rule in India. Executed at the age of 23 on March 23, 1931, he became a celebrated folk hero and a symbol of the Indian independence movement. His legacy grew significantly after his death.

Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut in the 2016 Indian Hindi-language biographical sports drama film *Dangal*, directed by Nitesh Tiwari. The film, which revolves around wrestling, starred Aamir Khan.

James VI and I (1566–1625) was King of Scotland from 1567 and King of England and Ireland from 1603 until his death, ruling both kingdoms in a personal union while they remained separate sovereign states with their own parliaments and laws. He advocated for a single parliament for England and Scotland but faced significant challenges with the English Parliament during his reign.

Danielle Cormack, born on December 26, 1970, is a New Zealand actress known for her roles in both stage and screen productions. She gained recognition as part of the original cast of the soap opera *Shortland Street* and for her role as Ephiny in *Xena: Warrior Princess*. Cormack has appeared in various television series and films, including *The Cult*, *Legend of the Seeker*, *Separation City*, and *Rake*. She also played Kate Leigh in *Underbelly: Razor*. Her most prominent recent role was as Bea Smith in the prison drama *Wentworth*, where she starred for four years until her departure in 2016.
Rob Sheridan, born on October 11, 1979, is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer renowned for his significant contributions to the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade is an actor known for starring and co-starring in several films, including *Tommy Boy*, *Black Sheep*, *Joe Dirt*, *Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser*, *Grown Ups*, and *Grown Ups 2*. *Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser*, a 2015 American comedy film, was directed by Fred Wolf and co-written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett, born on August 16, 1958, is an American actress.

Lady Gaga's album *Artpop* received mixed reviews from critics but achieved commercial success. It debuted at number one on the U.S. Billboard 200 with first-week sales of 258,000 copies, marking her second consecutive U.S. number-one album. By the end of 2013, *Artpop* had sold 757,000 copies in the U.S. and 2.3 million copies worldwide, making it the ninth best-selling album of that year.

In 2006, John Frusciante released his fifth and final album with the Red Hot Chili Peppers, titled *Stadium Arcadium*. This album marked the last time Frusciante, the band's guitarist, appeared on a Chili Peppers record, as he officially left the group in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher, a controversial and influential British Prime Minister, implemented policies known as Thatcherism. She is widely regarded as one of the greatest politicians in British history, though debates about her policies continue.

Michael Andrew "Duff" McKagan, born on February 5, 1964, is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author. Beyond his music career, McKagan has gained recognition as a writer, contributing weekly columns on diverse topics for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker, an English actor, has not only acted in various roles but has also provided narration for commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia, officially known as València, is the capital of the Valencian Community and the third-largest city in Spain, following Madrid and Barcelona. It has approximately 800,000 inhabitants in its administrative center and is part of Spain's third-largest metropolitan area, with a population ranging from 1.7 to 2.5 million. The Valencian Community, also referred to as the Valencian Country, is an autonomous region of Spain.
The passage describes Buffy Summers, a character portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and later by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
The series "Make It or Break It" concluded with its third season, which was announced as the final season on April 26, 2012. The series finale aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition (SR) is a multidisciplinary field within computational linguistics that focuses on developing technologies to convert spoken language into text. It integrates knowledge from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Applications of SR include voice user interfaces, voice dialing, call routing, appliance control, search functions, data entry, document preparation, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft control. The field has advanced significantly, driven by the adoption of deep learning methods, as evidenced by both academic research and industry adoption.
